Description: Body sherd of Chian black-figured Grand Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior: glazed black; exterior: at top, slightly diagonal added red and black incised bands; below, lion or possibly hound to right (only neck and paw remaining; red on neck and toothed collar), attacking a seated sphinx or lion (rump with red blob on thigh remaining).
Curator's comments: According to Williams, the chalice is probably by the same painter as Oxford AN1896-1908-G.133.2, AN1896-1908-G.133.6 and British Museum 1924,1201.206, 1924,1201.204 and 1924,1201.342, whom he has identified as the Sirens Painter. The Sirens Painter's pieces most closely resemble those by the Boreads Painter, primarily because of the single pomegranate band on the tondo of the Oxford kylix. Lemos identifies the sherd as belonging in the Sphinx and Lion Style but that is unlikely. There are very few drinking vessels in that style and lions and sphinxes are stylistically different.
In pencil on the inside '938' plus a letter or number in a square.
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 322, no. 1443, pl. 192.)
Williams 2006a / The Chian Pottery from Naukratis (p. 132 note 66)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.0872) (phase 2)
